title: 108_s1633
content: The Act may be cited as the "Identity Theft Notification and Credit Restoration Act of 2003". Congress finds that the privacy and financial security of individuals are increasingly at risk due to the widespread collection of personal information by both the private and public sector. Credit card transactions, real estate records, consumer surveys, credit reports, and Internet websites are all sources of personal information for identity thieves. Identity theft is one of the fastest-growing crimes in the United States, posing a major law enforcement challenge as criminals use stolen information to open fraudulent credit card accounts. Identity theft is a major law enforcement challenge in the new economy, with criminals using stolen personal information for financial crimes. In 2002, over 160,000 people reported identity theft to the Federal Trade Commission, costing consumers and the marketplace. Victims often have to contact multiple agencies and creditors to address the issue. Identity theft is a significant issue, with over 160,000 cases reported in 2002, costing consumers and the marketplace. Victims face the burden of contacting various agencies and creditors over many years. The government and private sector share the responsibility of protecting consumer information and assisting victims. Improving customer notification and fraud prevention can enhance consumer protection. The private sector has a responsibility to protect consumer information from identity thieves, assist identity theft victims, and mitigate harm from fraud. They can do this by improving customer notification, implementing fraud alerts, providing greater consumer access to credit reports, and establishing other financial identity theft prevention measures. SEC. 3. TIMELY NOTIFICATION OF UNAUTHORIZED ACCESS TO PERSONAL INFORMATION. Amendment to the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act requires notification to customers of unauthorized access to personal information. In this section, a breach is defined as the unauthorized acquisition of data compromising the security of personal information held by a financial institution. Personal information of a customer includes their first name or initial, last name, and other specified data. The term 'personal information' for a customer of a financial institution includes the first name or initial and last name, along with data elements like social security number, driver's license number, and credit card information. Notification of a breach of personal information is required. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers and consumer reporting agencies in case of a breach involving personal information, including credit card numbers or access codes. Financial institutions must promptly notify affected customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement agencies in case of a breach involving personal information. Any entity holding personal information for a financial institution must also notify the institution. Financial institutions are required to notify customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement of any breach involving personal information. Entities holding personal information for financial institutions must also promptly inform the institution of any breaches. Notification must be made promptly upon discovery of the breach, taking into account law enforcement needs and measures to determine the breach's scope. Financial institutions must promptly notify customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement of any breach or suspected breach. Notification should be made without unreasonable delay, considering law enforcement needs and measures to determine the breach's scope. Law enforcement delays may occur if notification would impede a criminal investigation, with notification required promptly after law enforcement determines it won't compromise the investigation. Notification can be provided to customers in various forms. Financial institutions must promptly notify customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement of any breach or suspected breach. Notification should be made without unreasonable delay, considering law enforcement needs and measures to determine the breach's scope. Law enforcement delays may occur if notification would impede a criminal investigation, with notification required promptly after law enforcement determines it won't compromise the investigation. Notification can be provided to customers in various forms, including in writing or electronically. Financial institutions must notify customers, consumer reporting agencies, and law enforcement promptly of any breach. Notification can be in writing or electronically, including an e-mail notice if customer contact information is insufficient. Financial institutions must provide sufficient customer contact information for notification in case of a breach, which can include an e-mail notice, a website posting, or media notification. Financial institutions must provide customer contact information for breach notification, which can include e-mail, website, or media alerts. Notifications must also be sent to credit reporting agencies and law enforcement as prescribed by the Federal Trade Commission. Each notification to a customer regarding a breach must include a statement informing them that credit reporting agencies have been notified and that their credit report will have a fraud alert. Additional information may be included as determined by the Federal Trade Commission. The Federal Trade Commission requires customer authorization for new credit issuance, along with other relevant information. Financial institutions must have a comprehensive security program and notify customers and agencies of breaches to comply with regulations. The financial institution must have a comprehensive information security program consistent with regulatory standards. They must notify affected customers and agencies of breaches, and internal security policies should align with notification requirements. Customers can seek damages for violations, and injunctions can be issued against financial institutions. Civil penalties for violations of this section include the ability for customers to seek damages and for injunctions to be issued against financial institutions. The rights and remedies under this section are in addition to those available under other laws. Compliance with this section by a financial institution does not constitute a violation of other laws prohibiting financial disclosure. The section provides rules of construction for financial institutions regarding the disclosure of information, stating that compliance with this section does not violate any other laws prohibiting financial disclosure. It also clarifies that financial institutions are not obligated to disclose information they are prohibited from disclosing under other laws. The section clarifies that financial institutions are not obligated to obtain, retain, or maintain information that is not required under other laws. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF FRAUD ALERTS IN CONSUMER CREDIT REPORTS. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include a definition of fraud alerts, which notify users of potential identity theft and unauthorized credit issuance. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in consumer files to prevent unauthorized credit issuance without consumer authorization. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include fraud alerts in consumer files to prevent unauthorized credit issuance without consumer authorization. Consumer reporting agencies must include a fraud alert in a consumer's file promptly upon notification by a financial institution or upon the consumer's request with appropriate evidence. The Fair Credit Reporting Act now requires consumer reporting agencies to promptly include a fraud alert in a consumer's file upon request with evidence of identity theft. The agency must also inform anyone accessing the consumer's credit information about the presence of a fraud alert. The Fair Credit Reporting Act mandates consumer reporting agencies to notify anyone accessing a consumer's credit information about the presence of a fraud alert in the consumer's file. The Federal Trade Commission will establish regulations for the duration and removal of fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act requires consumer reporting agencies to inform users of consumer credit reports about any fraud alerts present. Failure to comply with fraud alert procedures can result in violations for both consumer reporting agencies and users of consumer reports. Failure to comply with fraud alert procedures can result in violations for users of consumer reports, including issuing credit to the wrong person based on a fraud alert. Taking adverse action against a consumer solely because of a fraud alert is also a violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act. Access to credit reports and scores is addressed in Section 5. Section 612(c) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to provide consumers with free access to credit reports and scores upon request. A credit reporting agency can charge a reasonable fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. The Fair Credit Reporting Act allows credit reporting agencies to charge a reasonable fee for disclosures related to fraud alerts. Additionally, credit scores are now included in credit reports as per the amendments made to the Act. The Federal Trade Commission must issue final regulations within 180 days of this Act's enactment, in consultation with relevant financial regulatory agencies, to implement the amendments.
